column1: ~ 02:00|"about 2.00 a.m."|"At about 2.00 a.m. on 19 April
column2: their camp was invaded by about 200 armed Somalis. ‘Hearing a rush of men
column3: like a stormy wind’
column4: Burton sprang up
column5: and yelled at a servant to bring his sabre. Herne was sent out into the darkness to investigate and darted back into the tent having fired a few shots at the advancing attackers with his Colt. In his separate tent
column6: Speke heard Burton calling to Stroyan to get up
column7: and he also heard shots
column8: but at first he thought these were being fired at imaginary intruders by trigger-happy sentries. But hearing footsteps immediately outside
column9: he leapt from his bed and sprinted to Burton’s tent. While trying to do the same
column10: Stroyan was slashed across the head with a sword
column11: and then killed by a single spear-thrust to the heart."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: 12:00|noon|"In truth
column2: on his arrival at Ujiji
column3: Burton was too ill to write or even talk
column4: and lay prostrate on the earth floor of a hut for a fortnight
column5: unable to move his legs. He was also suffering from ophthalmia – although not as badly as Speke. Despite his brief period in command
column6: Speke was not prepared to make the next crucial decisions and waited for Burton to recover sufficiently for them to be able to discuss their next moves. Each day at noon
column7: ‘protected by an umbrella
column9: Speke visited Ujiji’s market. Here he purchased daily supplies for the porters and other servants. Displayed for sale were fish
column10: meat
column11: tobacco
column12: palm oil
column14: bananas
column15: melons
column16: sugar-cane and pulses. On certain days
column17: slaves and ivory could also be bought."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: 13:30|"1.30 p.m."|"The debate between the pair was due to take place at Bath’s Royal Mineral Water Hospital on 16 September 1864; and on the 15th
column2: Burton and Speke attended a preliminary meeting
column3: both sitting on the platform close to Sir Roderick Murchison. Burton claimed some years later that he had been shocked by how much older Speke looked after ‘his severe labours’. They glanced at one another without any sign of recognition. Someone beckoned to Speke from the hall at 1.30 p.m. and
column4: according to Burton
column5: he muttered: ‘I can’t stand this any longer!’
column6: and then left the building."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: ~ 14:30|"about 2.30 p.m."|"From Bath
column2: Speke rode to Neston Park
column3: Corsham
column4: the house of John B. Fuller
column5: an uncle whose estate was about ten miles away and with whom he was staying. Speke arrived at Neston Park at about 2.30 p.m. and soon afterwards went out shooting partridges with his cousin
column6: George P. Fuller. A keeper
column7: Daniel Davis
column8: came with them to mark birds. Throughout his adult life
column9: Speke had found shooting a soothing activity and he was very glad of it now."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: 02:00|"two in the morning"|"They were still 200 miles from their objective
column2: and frequently in danger
column3: despite Ibrahim’s presence (indeed partly because of it). Over again they heard the war drums ring out and were obliged to build barricades with their baggage. On one particularly menacing occasion
column4: Florence laid out several hundred cartridges of buckshot
column5: powder flasks and wadding on a mat
column6: while Baker lined up his guns and rifles. Even little Saat strapped on his belt and cartouche-box and took his stand among the men
column7: but at two in the morning
column8: after many anxious hours of waiting
column9: the dense crowds of armed men began to disperse. The Latuka had recently trapped a caravan of 300 Arabs
column10: and after chasing them to the verge of a precipice
column11: had thrust them over it with their spears. So the dangers were real enough. Meanwhile Baker’s own men continued to alarm him
column12: and he was fortunate to end a near mutiny by knocking out the ringleader with a lucky punch."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: 12:00|noonday|"The glory of our prize burst suddenly upon me! There
column2: like a sea of quicksilver
column3: lay far beneath
column4: the grand expanse of water – a boundless sea horizon on the south and south-west
column5: glittering in the noonday sun; and on the west
column6: at fifty or sixty miles’ distance
column7: blue mountains rose from the bosom of the lake to a height of about 7
column8: 000 feet … It is impossible to describe the triumph of that moment … England had won the sources of the Nile!"|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"Workhouse inmates wore suits made from fustian (rough flannel); they rose at six
column2: washed in cold water
column3: performed menial tasks
column4: and if admitted with parents or brothers and sisters were immediately separated from them. However
column5: some of the abler children learned to read
column6: write
column7: and do simple sums. While at the workhouse
column8: John read David Livingstone’s first book
column10: which made a lasting impression on him. Very few of his fellow pupils could have mastered a book like that. Educational standards had been very low when Rowlands had arrived at St Asaph
column11: but improved steadily during his long residence."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column1: 04:00|"four in the morning"|"At four in the morning
column2: he burst into Susi’s hut and begged him to come at once. A dim glow came from the entrance of the hut. A candle stuck with its own wax on to the top of a box was still burning. Livingstone was half-dressed and kneeling on his bed with his head resting on the pillow. It looked as though he was praying. Susi and the others did not go in at once but waited for some movement. When it did not come
column3: they went in and one of them touched the kneeling man’s cheek. It was almost cold. David Livingstone had been dead for several hours."|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"

column2: 800 Mahdists had been killed and 16
column3: 000 wounded. Kitchener lost a mere 48 killed and 382 wounded. George W. Steevens of the Daily Mail praised Kitchener’s men for their steadiness
column4: but admitted: ‘The honour of the fight must still go with the men who died.’"|"Explorers of the Nile"|"Tim Jeal"
